Ian Badcoe wrote:

>This question of the shape and size of fitness landscapes is one that has 
>intrigued me for years.  I have a few intuitions about them which you might 
>like to argue with:
>
>1) They're big.  And for any really interesting question (like how to play 
>chess) they're not big like the universe is big, they're _much_ larger than 
>that.
>  
>
Also, quite often they have a lot more than 3 dimensions.

>3) Increased connectivity pulls points closer together and speeds evolution.
>
>4) Increased connectivity increases the size of "neighborhood" around each 
>point, and slows evolution.
>
>5) So there's a trade-off between 3 and 4, which is problem dependent and 
>nobody knows how to estimate the best compromise.
>  
>
Putting my phased search hat on for a moment. Perhaps switching between 
different types of mutation could be beneficial, the search could spend 
time finding a local optimum in the current landscape, and then we 
change the landscape to search for wdier solutions, if we find one then 
switch back to searching for local solutions. This is a generalisation 
of course, you could have many different fitness landscape schemes to 
choose from. So just periodically cycling through different schemes 
might be better than any one scheme on it's own. One very rudamentary 
implementation of this idea would be to periodically take a champion 
genome from NEAT and to just perform weight mutation (no topology 
mutations), in order to find the optimal weights fro the current best 
toplogy.

>         Again this brings home to me that any evolving software technique 
>really needs functional, automatic modularity before it has any hope of 
>breaking into the BIG problems.  Modularity entails a trade off very like 
>(5) in that the presence of modularity increases the size of the overall 
>search space (adding choices about how to define modules) but hugely 
>decreases the size of the parts that are considered at one time (e.g. each 
>modules fitness landscape is much, much smaller than the overall fitness 
>landscape.).
>  
>
In the mean time it's a good idea to investigate the limits of direct 
encoding techniques such as NEAT. With a great many experiments and all 
ideas exhausted research can them move on to modular or indirect 
approaches, using the best direct encoding technques as a benchmark.  I 
also think that NEAT could form the core of an indirect encoding 
technique in the future, finding sub-solutions that can then be 
recombined into larger solutions. I think I just walked into that trap 
of thinking in a 'divide and conquer' / engineering manner again :)

Anyway I have serious doubts about how well indirect techniques can work 
without much faster computers or at least enough money to buy computers 
fast enough. e.g. see 
http://www.geek.com/news/geeknews/2004Jul/bch20040730026275.htm

Anyone got $3.5 million to spare? :)
